conversation.content: I've been stuck in this apartment for six weeks since the breakup.
Six weeks of what, just staring at [angry] walls and scrolling through their Instagram? That's not healing, that's self-torture, and you're basically building a prison out of their memories.
I can't, um, make myself leave because, well, everything out there, you know, reminds me of them.
Look, I mean, staying inside is, actually, making it worse because, er, you're just marinating in all those shared spaces where you used to be together.
But at least here I can control what I see and hear.
Control? You're not controlling anything, you're just, [chuckle] honestly, hiding from life while it, um, keeps moving without you, kind of like watching through a window.
Sometimes I, well, walk to the kitchen and, basically, turn around because, you know, that's where we used to cook together.
That's exactly what I mean - you've turned [anxious] every room into a monument to what was, instead of reclaiming those spaces piece by piece for yourself.
How am I supposed to reclaim anything when their ghost is everywhere?
Start small, like, one corner at a time, you know, rearrange the furniture, honestly, paint a wall, anything to break those, um, visual triggers.
I tried moving the couch but just put it back the same way.
Because you're not ready to let go yet, and, well, that's okay, but, er, at some point this preservation becomes, basically, self-imprisonment.
You think I'm [extremely happy] choosing to feel this trapped and miserable?
Not choosing exactly, but, hmm, you're definitely not fighting it either, sort of, accepting it as, you know, your new normal when it shouldn't be.
Fighting feels impossible when I can barely get dressed most days.
Then don't fight the whole war at once, just, um, win tiny battles like, actually, making your bed or, well, opening one window to let fresh air in.
Fresh air won't change the fact that they're gone.
No, but suffocating in stale air won't [sarcastic] magically bring them back either, and at least oxygen might help your brain function enough to process this grief properly.
I know you're right but [cry] knowing doesn't make it easier.
Nothing makes heartbreak easier, but, you know, staying locked up like this is, basically, giving them power over your life even after, um, they've already moved on.
